summary: Michael Sheen
body:
Michael Sheen

Please, please!!! Listen to this podcast with our lovely men David Tennant and Michael Sheen.

David interviews Michael and he talks about his career, how he was almost an Arsenal player, how his dad made a career as Jack Nicholson’s double and a lot more of fascinating stories.

Promise, you won’t regret it!

blog.name: aeide-thea
blog.title: hir own small widgeon cries
blog.description:
[because such revisitations constitute a life]

¶

“significant introspective access and high-vulnerability lyricism”
—tumblr user @unopenablebox

not a minor but A minor, with major interludes

¶

adele + bicycling + alison bechdel’s are you my mother? + board games + body positivity + books + boots

isabelle boulay + brains behaving badly + bright colors + a bright particular star or two

lois mcmaster bujold’s vorkosigan saga + a.s. byatt + cabernet sauvignon + cats + civilization v + classics

interesting cocktails + coffee + colorful hair + colors more generally + compassion + susan cooper’s

the dark is rising sequence + craft beer + crossword puzzles + cyrano de bergerac + robertson davies

depression + detective fiction + doc martens + diane duane + dorothy dunnett + (coming to

terms with) embodiment + fairytales + fanfic + fannishness + feelingsblogging + feminism + femme boys

firefly + folk rock + freedom & necessity + good omens + graphic design + ancient greek

georgette heyer + struggling towards human connection + industrial design + INFP + interior design

intersectionality + introspection + introversion + diana wynne jones + journaling + language + makeupping

joni mitchell + le morte d’arthur + mythology + nailbiting + new york, ny + joanna newsom

laura nyro + perfectionism + piercings + pining + pixie cuts + poetry + sometimes polyamory

procrastination + psychology + philip pullman’s his dark materials trilogy + queerness

questioning/queering gender + rock climbing + rowing + saint ann’s school + dorothy sayers

scaramouche + selfies + sentiment + simon & garfunkel + singing + social anxiety + social justice

star trek + star wars + style + judith tarr + j.r.r. tolkien + les trois mousquetaires + typography

very slow progress towards a bachelor’s degree + virgo, but not too serious about it + david foster wallace’s

essays + the west wing + p.g. wodehouse + defensively and desirously aligned with women and femmes

and trans people of all stripes—

tags: mostly this is not a fannish blog but sometimes u just gotta archive stuff
summary: i can't seem to find the video of this interaction anywhere that would let me embed it on my blog, which is hella disappointing,...
body:
i can’t seem to find the video of this interaction anywhere that would let me embed it on my blog, which is hella disappointing, but it’s here on bbc america if you can access that, or here on bbc iplayer? anyway the relevant exchange is like 4:10-30 (or start at like 3:40 if you want the preamble), and it’s delightful:

graham norton asks michael sheen about vocal warmups (which i always forget are a thing for stage actors just as much as they are for singers!) with a ‘particularly welsh slant’ (sheen being welsh), and sheen rattles off one he’s coined and is adorably proud of (‘in aberystwyth / there is a locksmith / his name is dai smith’), and then says ‘but then the biggest one, which no one else can do, is that very long place name in wales—’

and david tennant goes, ‘well, you say no one else can do it…’ and there’s this long pause, and the two of them sort of lock eyes with each other, and michael sheen breaks out into this disbelieving little grin and goes, ‘no. there’s no way. there’s no way you can know that!’ and tennant just kind of sits up a little, and resettles his suit jacket, and calmly but trippingly says to him ‘Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.’

and sheen goes, ‘oh my god.’ and literally rocks back in his seat like he doesn’t even know what to do with himself, he’s so delighted. and tennant is just nursing this tiny little grin, and it’s just. ugh they’re so good! their dynamic is so good. i love how much tennant plays up to sheen and how ready sheen is to be charmed by him—i know i’m charmed by both of them. what a good. ♥

(tangential fun fact: the town name in question apparently appeared in a cryptic crossword once, under the clue ‘Giggling troll follows Clancy, Larry, Billy and Peggy who howl, wrongly disturbing a place in Wales (58),’ where all but the last five words formed an anagram. something about this GIANT ANAGRAM is just hugely delightful to me, omg—also, holy shit, how enormous must this crossword grid have been!)

summary: "Where the heaven's sake have you gone, you idiot? For God- for Satan- For someone's sake! You've gone. Somebody killed my best...

“Where the heaven’s sake have you gone, you idiot? For God- for Satan- For someone’s sake! You’ve gone. Somebody killed my best friend. Bastards! All of you!”

- Crowley (cause I didn’t know I needed to cry today)

summary: I feel like every time I see David Tennant in a new show, he gets a little bit sluttier and his legs get very slightly longer....
body: I feel like every time I see David Tennant in a new show, he gets a little bit sluttier and his legs get very slightly longer. Directors find it impossible to contain his raw power. His hips swing solely to the tempo of Stayin’ Alive by the Bee Gees.

summary: 'Good Omens': Michael Sheen and David Tennant on How Neil Gaiman Picked His Angel and Demon
title: 'Good Omens': Michael Sheen and David Tennant on How Neil Gaiman Picked His Angel and Demon
excerpt: "Good Omens" stars Michael Sheen and David Tennant tell TheWrap how they were cast by Neil Gaiman for Amazon Prime Video's adaptation.
description:
“I became friends with Neil quite a few years ago now, and so when it got to the point where he started writing the adaptation of this, he would send me the early versions of the scripts,” said the Welsh-born Sheen, 50, whose work includes “The Queen,” “Frost/Nixon” and “Masters of Sex.”

“I can’t remember how it happened, but I think there was a sort of assumption on my part, and his part, that each of us wanted me to play Crowley. But when I started reading the scripts I thought, ‘I can’t do this. That’s not the right part for me. I wouldn’t be able to get away with it.’ I really responded and related to Aziraphale. But I was scared that Neil didn’t want me to play Aziraphale, and he was scared that I wanted to play Crowley and I wouldn’t want to play Aziraphale!”

“So we had an awkward dinner where both of us wanted to address the fact that I should play Aziraphale and each was scared to say it to the other,” he continued. “And then Neil just sort of dove in at one point and said, ‘Look, how would you feel about playing Aziraphale?’ And I said ‘Oh, thank God! Thank God!’ And fairly soon afterward he said, ‘I want David to play Crowley.’ And I thought, ‘Well, I can’t imagine anyone better or anyone I could be more excited to really get to act with.‘”

Tennant, a Scottish actor two years younger than Sheen whose credits include “Broadchurch,” “Doctor Who” and “Jessica Jones,” added, “I was blissfully unaware of all this going on behind the scenes. To me, a script arrived and Michael was already part of the project, and Douglas Mackinnon, a director I knew and had worked for before, was already part of the project. So I just got this wonderful, fully formed masterpiece in an email from Neil Gaiman and it was an easy yes. I read the first two scripts and said yes before they could say they wanted anyone else.”

reblog.comment:
“I became friends with Neil quite a few years ago now, and so when it got to the point where he started writing the adaptation of this, he would send me the early versions of the scripts,” said the Welsh-born Sheen, 50, whose work includes “The Queen,” “Frost/Nixon” and “Masters of Sex.”

“I can’t remember how it happened, but I think there was a sort of assumption on my part, and his part, that each of us wanted me to play Crowley. But when I started reading the scripts I thought, ‘I can’t do this. That’s not the right part for me. I wouldn’t be able to get away with it.’ I really responded and related to Aziraphale. But I was scared that Neil didn’t want me to play Aziraphale, and he was scared that I wanted to play Crowley and I wouldn’t want to play Aziraphale!”

“So we had an awkward dinner where both of us wanted to address the fact that I should play Aziraphale and each was scared to say it to the other,” he continued. “And then Neil just sort of dove in at one point and said, ‘Look, how would you feel about playing Aziraphale?’ And I said ‘Oh, thank God! Thank God!’ And fairly soon afterward he said, ‘I want David to play Crowley.’ And I thought, ‘Well, I can’t imagine anyone better or anyone I could be more excited to really get to act with.‘”

Tennant, a Scottish actor two years younger than Sheen whose credits include “Broadchurch,” “Doctor Who” and “Jessica Jones,” added, “I was blissfully unaware of all this going on behind the scenes. To me, a script arrived and Michael was already part of the project, and Douglas Mackinnon, a director I knew and had worked for before, was already part of the project. So I just got this wonderful, fully formed masterpiece in an email from Neil Gaiman and it was an easy yes. I read the first two scripts and said yes before they could say they wanted anyone else.”
